title: 114_s1603
content: The "Border Jobs for Veterans Act of 2015" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress finds that Customs and Border Protection Officers play a critical role in law enforcement at US ports of entry. It is important to adequately staff these ports with officers, including meeting the staffing target of 23,775 officers for fiscal year 2015. Additionally, efforts to recruit and hire qualified individuals separating from the military need to be enhanced. Customs and Border Protection Officers play a critical role in law enforcement at US ports of entry. Efforts to recruit qualified individuals separating from military service for vacant officer positions need to be enhanced. SEC. 3. EXPEDITED HIRING OF APPROPRIATE SEPARATING SERVICE MEMBERS. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in conjunction with the Secretary of Defense, will identify transferable Military Occupational Specialty Codes and Officer Branches, Air Force Specialty Codes, Naval Enlisted Classifications, and Coast Guard Competencies for Customs and Border Protection Officers. Qualified candidates with these codes may be considered for hiring under veterans recruitment appointment. Enhancements to existing programs aim to recruit service members separating from military service for Customs and Border Protection officer vacancies. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in collaboration with the Secretary of Defense, will enhance recruiting efforts to enlist separating Armed Forces members as Customs and Border Protection Officers. This includes incorporating officer opportunities in job assistance programs, having officials present at recruiting events, and offering local recruitment opportunities. The collaboration between the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense aims to enhance recruiting efforts for separating Armed Forces members to become Customs and Border Protection Officers. This includes partnering with military bases, educating members on transferable skills, and identifying shared activities for hiring reciprocity. The collaboration between the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense aims to streamline the hiring process for Customs and Border Protection Officers by transferring background investigations and security clearances efficiently. Additionally, it ensures that separating Armed Forces members are informed about opportunities to fill vacant positions. SEC. 5. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress detailing efforts to hire separating service members as Customs and Border Protection Officers, including enhanced recruiting efforts, goals, and how they will meet staffing levels and hiring benchmarks. The report to Congress must include details on efforts to hire separating service members as Customs and Border Protection Officers, including recruiting efforts, staffing levels, Military Occupational Specialty Codes, vacancies filled, and veterans recruitment appointments. SEC. 6. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not supersede existing Federal veterans' hiring preferences or hiring authorities, nor does it authorize additional appropriations.
